title: Tokyo Day 2 - Yoyogi, Observation Deck, Bath House
content:
This morning Tristan had a bit of work to go to, so I tagged along to Shibuya. The area around the station has recently been renovated (ongoing), so I had a look at the ‚Äústream‚Äù development with all the new shops fronting it - is a very nice strip lined with plum blossoms that might be in bloom soon!

Next I headed to Yoyogi park and Meiji shrine, stopping for a coffee along the way. The day was really nice just to relax a little and go at a slower pace through the park. The shrine had a lot of signs along the path showing the history since it was completed - this year marks the 100th anniversary. There is a public holiday on Tuesday, and there seemed to be a lot of indications the place will be filled then.

After spending a good bit of time in the park, I had to head back to Shibuya to meet Tristan for lunch. We met near the Hachiko statue (a popular meeting place), then found a sushi train for lunch - this was mostly very nice (only one dish didn‚Äôt do it for me)! Quite well-priced as well.

We continued on to Shinjuku after lunch, and went up the metropolitan government building to the observation deck for a look over the city. The day was somewhat clear, but not enough to see Mt Fuji.

I spotted a flea market in a nearby park while we were high up, so we went there to take a look for something different, then we headed back to the house to chat and play some games for a bit of relaxation üòÅ.

Naoko made dinner tonight (oyakodon plus other vegetables) - this was a delicious meal that looked like it came from a restaurant!

Finally for the day was a visit to their local bath house. This was such a great experience! So much larger than I expected, and the variety of baths and things to do was fantastic - cold baths, hot baths (indoor and outdoor), saunas, jet (spa) baths, electro bath, and a water floor thing that you lay on to relax! We spent time in most of these totalling about an hour and a half. Then we enjoyed some green tea in a tatami seating area before we headed home. So much more of an experience than I was expecting it to be!
